comments: JOINKEY is a special UDF that is used to include, and alias, the synthetic column created by some joins.
If used elsewhere it works in the same way as COALESCE

tests.name: inner join with synthetic key
statements: CREATE STREAM L (ID INT KEY, V0 INT, V1 INT) WITH (kafka_topic='left_topic', value_format='JSON');
CREATE STREAM R (ID INT KEY, V0 INT, V1 INT) WITH (kafka_topic='right_topic', value_format='JSON');
CREATE STREAM OUTPUT as SELECT JOINKEY(ABS(L.ID), ABS(R.ID)) AS ID, L.ID, R.ID, L.V0, R.V1 FROM L INNER JOIN R WITHIN 1 SECOND ON ABS(L.id) = ABS(R.id);

sources.name: OUTPUT
sources.schema: ID INT KEY, L_ID INT, R_ID INT, L_V0 INT, R_V1 INT

statements: CREATE TABLE L (ID INT PRIMARY KEY, V0 INT, V1 INT) WITH (kafka_topic='left_topic', value_format='JSON');
CREATE TABLE R (ID INT PRIMARY KEY, V0 INT, V1 INT) WITH (kafka_topic='right_topic', value_format='JSON');

expectedException.message:
The query used to build `OUTPUT` must include the join expression JOINKEY(ABS(L.ID), ABS(R.ID)) in its projection.
JOINKEY(ABS(L.ID), ABS(R.ID)) was added as a synthetic key column because the join criteria did not match any source column.
